title: Christian Hilt
text:
Christian Gottlieb Hilt (29 January 1888 – 5 August 1958) was a <a href="Norway">Norwegian</a> newspaper editor and politician for the <a href="Norwegian%20Labour%20Party">Labour</a> and <a href="Communist%20Party%20of%20Norway">Communist</a> parties.
Hilt was born in <a href="Bergen">Bergen</a>, and started studies in 1906 but left the higher education system after a couple of years. He instead became subeditor in the newspaper "<a href="Demokraten">Smaalenenes Social-Demokrat</a>", and was acting editor-in-chief from 1910 to 1911. Hilt then worked in "<a href="Rogalands%20Avis">Den 1ste Mai</a>", "<a href="Bratsberg-Demokraten">Bratsberg-Demokraten</a>" and "<a href="Dagsavisen">Social-Demokraten</a>". In 1914, he was hired in "<a href="Fremtiden">Fremtiden</a>", where he was promoted to subeditor in October, and in 1916 he was hired in "<a href="Ny%20Tid%20%28Trondheim%29">Ny Tid</a>" where he became editor in 1918. Already in 1919, Hilt left "Ny Tid" to become a manager in the news bureau <a href="Avisenes%20nyhetsbyr%C3%A5">Arbeidernes Pressekontor</a>. He was also a <a href="List%20of%20delegates%20of%20the%204th%20Comintern%20congress">delegate</a> at the Fourth <a href="Comintern">Comintern</a> Congress in 1922, and participated in the <a href="Executive%20Committee%20of%20the%20Communist%20International%23World%20Congresses%20of%20the%20Comintern%20and%20Plenums%20of%20ECCI">4th and 7th Enlarged Plenums</a> of the <a href="Executive%20Committee%20of%20the%20Communist%20International">Executive Committee of the Comintern</a> in 1926 and 1927.
In 1923, Hilt broke away from the Labour Party, joining the Communist Party. He was elected party secretary in 1925, and was a politburo member from 1926 to 1929. He had two spells as editor-in-chief for "<a href="Norges%20Kommunistblad">Norges Kommunistblad</a>", from July 1926 to the spring of 1927 and from the autumn 1927 to 1929. The hiatus came because Hilt stayed in the <a href="Soviet%20Union">Soviet Union</a> for a period. Around 1926–1927, he also served on the editorial board of "<a href="Proletaren">Proletaren</a>". Hilt then stayed in the Soviet Union from 1929 to 1936, where he did various work for Comintern, and was a correspondent for newspapers all over <a href="Scandinavia">Scandinavia</a>. In 1937, Hilt returned to Norway as secretary of a Norway–Soviet friendship association. He also edited a communist periodical "Nytt Land" from 1937 to 1940.
During the <a href="occupation%20of%20Norway%20by%20Nazi%20Germany">occupation of Norway by Nazi Germany</a>, Hilt was a member of the <a href="Norwegian%20resistance%20movement">Norwegian resistance movement</a>. He was described by <a href="Heinrich%20Fehlis">Heinrich Fehlis</a> in an August 1940 edition of "<a href="Meldungen%20aus%20Norwegen">Meldungen aus Norwegen</a>". When the <a href="Underground%20media%20in%20German-occupied%20Europe">illegal newspaper</a> "<a href="Friheten">Friheten</a>" started in 1941, Hilt edited it together with <a href="Erling%20Heiestad">Erling Heiestad</a>. The newspaper was <a href="stencil">stencil</a>ed, and published fortnightly. Hilt also edited "Radio-Nytt". While Heiestad was arrested in 1941, Hilt made good his escape to <a href="Sweden%20during%20World%20War%20II">neutral Sweden</a>.
After the war, Hilt was again secretary of a new Norway–Soviet friendship association. He died in August 1958, and is buried at Østre Aker.
